content.text: Measure and record the length \(l\) and the width \(w\) of the sample A of modelling clay. Fig. 1.1 is drawn actual size
Calculate the volume \(V_{\mathrm{A}}\) of sample A using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{A}} = l \times w \times d\)
Fig. 1.2 shows sample A on a balance. Record the mass \(m_{\mathrm{A}}\) of sample A to the nearest g
Calculate the density \(\rho_{\mathrm{A}}\) of sample A of modelling clay using the equation \(\rho_{\mathrm{A}} = \frac{m_{\mathrm{A}}}{V_{\mathrm{A}}}\)
Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this method and include the unit
Method 2
Fig. 1.1 shows one face of a piece of modelling clay that the student uses. This is sample A
The student measures the depth \(d\) of sample A
Calculate the volume \(V_{\mathrm{B}}\) of sample B using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{B}} = V_{2} - V_{1}\)
The student measures the mass \(m_{\mathrm{B}}\) of sample B
Calculate the density \(\rho_{\mathrm{B}}\) of sample B using the equation \(\rho_{\mathrm{B}} = \frac{m_{\mathrm{B}}}{V_{\mathrm{B}}}\). Give your answer to a
suitable number of significant figures for this method and include the unit
The student records the volume \(V_{1}\) of water in a measuring cylinder
He carefully lowers sample B of the same modelling clay into the measuring cylinder until it is completely covered with water
He records the new reading \(V_{2}\) of the water level in the measuring cylinder
A student suggests that the density of modelling clay is not affected by the mass or the volume of the sample used
State whether your results agree with the suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to your results
statement
justification
Tick the boxes that describe the correct line of sight for taking a reading of the volume of water in a measuring cylinder. Fig. 1.3 shows the curved surface of water, which is called the meniscus
along the scale
parallel to the scale
perpendicular to the scale
vertical to the scale
in line with the bottom of the meniscus
in line with the top of the meniscus
in line with midway between the top and bottom of the meniscus
A student determines the density of modelling clay by two methods
**Method 1**
The thermometer in Fig. 2.2 shows the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) at the beginning of the experiment. Record \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
Complete the time column and the column headings in Table 2.1
Calculate the drop in temperature \(\Delta \theta_{1}\) between times \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180\) s
\(\Delta \theta_{1} =\)
Calculate the average rate of cooling \(R_{1}\) of the water using the equation \(R_{1} = \frac{\Delta \theta_{1}}{\Delta t}\),
where \(\Delta t = 180 \text{s}\). Include the unit
The student pours \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker
She records the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0\). She immediately starts a stopclock
After 180 s, she measures the temperature \(\theta\) shown on the thermometer. Her temperature readings are shown in Table 2.1
Complete the time column and the column headings in Table 2.2
Calculate the drop in temperature \(\Delta \theta_{2}\) between times \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
\(\Delta \theta_{2} =\)

The student empties the beaker. She pours \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. She adds \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water to the beaker. She repeats the timing and temperature recording procedure described in **(b)**. The temperature readings are shown in Table 2.2
Calculate the difference \(D_{1}\) using the readings in Table 2.1 and your answer to (a)
Calculate the difference \(D_{2}\) using the readings in Table 2.2 and your answer to (a)
Write a conclusion about the relationship between \(R\) and \(D\). Justify your answer by reference to your results
conclusion
justification
A student suggests that the average rate of cooling \(R\) of the water depends on the difference \(D\) between the temperature of the water at time \(t = 0\) and room temperature
Explain why the thermometer scale should be read at right-angles
Explain why the mixture of hot and cold water should be stirred before taking the temperature reading at the start of the experiment in (c)
A student investigates the cooling of water under different conditions
Fig. 2.1 shows the apparatus she uses
On Fig. 3.2, measure and record the height \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\) of the object
The student places the lens a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object
â¢ He moves the screen slowly until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen
â¢ He measures the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen
â¢ He repeats the procedure using values of \(u\) equal to \(25.0 \text{cm}\), \(30.0 \text{cm}\), \(35.0 \text{cm}\) and \(40.0 \text{cm}\)
â¢ The readings are shown in Table 3.1
Plot a graph of \(u / \text{cm}\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(m\) (\(x\)-axis). Start the \(y\)-axis at \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\)
Use your graph to determine the value of the object distance \(u_{1}\) when the magnification \(m = 1.0\)
Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
Calculate the focal length \(f\) of the lens using the equation \(f = \frac{u_{1}}{2}\)
State two precautions that you would take with this experiment in order to obtain accurate readings
A student investigates the magnification of the image produced by a lens
Fig. 3.1 shows the apparatus used
Fig. 3.2 shows a triangular hole in a card that forms the illuminated object. Fig. 3.2 is drawn actual size
A student investigates the resistances of different wires
Plan an experiment to investigate the resistances of wires made from different metals
Resistance is calculated using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
The following apparatus is available:
ammeter
voltmeter
power supply
metre rule
a selection of wires made from different metals
You can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory
In your plan, you should:
â¢ write a list of suitable metals for the wires you will investigate
â¢ draw a diagram of a suitable electrical circuit using standard electrical symbols
â¢ explain briefly how to carry out the investigation
â¢ state the key variables to keep constant
â¢ draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
